articles.title: Dave Smith, Whose Synthesizers Shaped Electronic Music, Dies at 72
articles.description: His innovations included the first polyphonic, programmable synthesizer and the universal connectivity of MIDI.

articles.title: Twitter Said to Agree to Give Elon Musk Access to Stream of Tweets
articles.description: The move may make it tougher for Mr. Musk, who has said he is not getting enough information from the company, to end the $44 billion acquisition.

articles.title: Scooters Get a Second Chance
articles.description: Electric scooters have had their share of haters, but some cities have found ways to make them more appealing.

articles.title: What Texas Gains by Investigating Twitter’s Fake Accounts
articles.description: For Ken Paxton, the state attorney general, there are positives. Aligning with Elon Musk? Check. Politically helpful? Check.

articles.title: How Safe Are Systems Like Tesla’s Autopilot? No One Knows.
articles.description: Automakers and technology companies say they are making driving safer, but verifying these claims is difficult.

articles.title: Fraud and Identity Theft Trial to Test American Anti-Hacking Law
articles.description: A woman is accused of downloading data of more than 100 million Capital One customers. Her lawyers argue a conviction would criminalize legitimate research practices.

articles.title: Europe wants to help clear out your drawer full of chargers.
articles.description: A European Union mandate set to begin in 2026 will require all new smartphones, tablets and laptops to use a common charger.

articles.title: A Short History of Tech Predictions
articles.description: What do Google Glass and Pokémon Go have in common? They didn’t change the world.

articles.title: F.D.A. advisers recommend the authorization of Covid shots by Novavax, a latecomer in the vaccine race.
articles.description: Clinical trials found the vaccine to work well, but the company has long struggled with manufacturing.

articles.title: Can a Start-Up Make Sustainable Construction the Next Frontier in Eco-Business?
articles.description: Nexii Building Solutions in Vancouver is having significant early success, though there are potential pitfalls.

articles.title: Zahn McClarnon Sets His Thousand-Yard Stare on the Lead
articles.description: AMC’s new thriller “Dark Winds” represents several firsts for the Indigenous actor, who has built a long career playing roles of quiet intensity.

articles.title: In ‘The Baby,’ Killing With Cuteness
articles.description: This British horror-comedy, which has its season finale on Sunday, literalizes the terrors of motherhood.

articles.title: SZA’s ‘Ctrl’ Bonus, and 8 More New Songs
articles.description: Hear tracks by Saucy Santana, Demi Lovato, Joyce Manor and others.

articles.title: ‘Dark Winds’ Review: Murder Most Foul in the Navajo Nation
articles.description: A six-episode adaptation of Tony Hillerman’s tribal-police mysteries finally puts the invaluable actor Zahn McClarnon at the top of the cast list.

articles.title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
articles.description: “Peaky Blinders” is back. Or check out a new AMC thriller starring Zahn McClarnon.

articles.title: In ‘For All Mankind,’ the Future Is in the Past
articles.description: Apple TV+’s refreshingly retro space thriller reverse-engineers history to find an interplanetary path not taken. (Next stop, Mars!)

articles.title: Chris Blackwell Is Music’s Quietest ‘Record Man.’ His Artists Speak Loudly.
articles.description: In a new memoir, the 84-year-old founder of Island Records reflects on helping bring the music of Bob Marley, U2 and Grace Jones to the world.

articles.title: Mailbag Madness: Adele, Jack Harlow, the State of Rock’s Return
articles.description: The team answers your questions about Chance the Rapper, how the critics consider extramusical concerns and more.

articles.title: ‘Jurassic World Dominion’ Review: Extinction Rebellion
articles.description: Things get very hectic in the last episode of this trilogy, which brings back familiar faces (Jeff Goldblum, Laura Dern, Sam Neill) along with the usual dinosaurs.

articles.title: The Daily Revelations of Kellyoke
articles.description: Kelly Clarkson has covered more than 500 songs on her syndicated daytime series. The segments are one of the last predictably good things on network TV.

articles.title: The Week in Business: Trouble for Tesla?
articles.description: Inflation recorded another increase; the Fed will probably follow with a new rate bump. And Wells Fargo is under criminal investigation.

articles.title: A Stalled High-Speed Line in North England
articles.description: Transport problems have long hobbled northern England, and an ambitious rail project was meant to ease these woes. I went to the region to explore the initiative and to see how northerners felt after a portion of it didn't go as initially planned.

articles.title: Howard Schultz: Starbucks Is Battling for the ‘Hearts and Minds’ of Workers
articles.description: Mr. Schultz, the chief executive of Starbucks, discussed the challenges he’s faced since returning to lead the company as it faces rising worker discontent and China’s ever-increasing role in global business.

articles.title: The Pralines, Pecan Log Rolls and Nostalgia Fueling the Stuckey’s Revival
articles.description: The pandemic reinvigorated car travel and, with it, the market for snacks and Americana. Will it last?

articles.title: It Works for Sneakers. Now It’s for Baby PJs and Skateboards, Too.
articles.description: A wide range of retailers are manufacturing excitement, and scarcity, with limited edition product “drops.”

articles.title: Who Is the Former TV News Chief Helping the Jan. 6 Committee?
articles.description: James Goldston was a longtime producer at ABC News and then its president for seven years.

articles.title: At Least 20 Million Watched Jan. 6 Hearing
articles.description: The number is in the ballpark of big television events like a “Sunday Night Football” game.

articles.title: An ‘Ugly’ Inflation Report Upended Hopes That Price Gains Would Ease
articles.description: Investors and economists had expected to see some moderation in inflation. Instead, prices accelerated again in May, delivering an unwanted surprise.

articles.title: After a Political Storm, Gay Days Return to Disney
articles.description: An L.G.B.T.Q. tradition at Disney World took on new significance this year, when Disney was ensnared in a heated cultural debate.

articles.title: U.S. Scrutinizes Swiss Currency Practices
articles.description: The Treasury Department declined to label any country a currency manipulator, but singled out Switzerland as an offender in its semiannual foreign exchange report.

articles.title: Alexander Nikitin, Who Coached a Chess Champion, Dies at 87
articles.description: Garry Kasparov was just 10 when Mr. Nikitin took him on as a student. By age 17, with Mr. Nikitin as his coach, he was a grandmaster.

articles.title: The Celtics Got Lucky by Not Getting What They Wanted
articles.description: Other teams’ superstars kept getting traded, and the Celtics wanted in on the action. Boston (mostly) missed out, and is probably better off for it.

articles.title: Don Perkins, Star Dallas Running Back, Is Dead at 84
articles.description: He rushed for 6,217 yards in 107 games with the Cowboys from 1961 to 1968 and ranks fourth on the team’s career list.

articles.title: Steph Curry Is Boosting Black Designers at the N.B.A. Finals
articles.description: The Golden State fashion plate has made a point of wearing looks from independent labels during his “tunnel walks.”

articles.title: Chile Loses Bid to Replace Ecuador at World Cup
articles.description: Chile’s soccer federation had argued Ecuador should be ejected from the tournament for using an ineligible player in qualifying. FIFA disagreed.

articles.title: In the Club and the Clubhouse, a Coach Adds Some Flavor
articles.description: His passion is playing percussion at salsa clubs, but Charlie Montoyo also thrives at his day job: managing the Toronto Blue Jays.

articles.title: What Is LIV Golf? It Depends Whom You Ask.
articles.description: Bold new project or crass money grab? Even golf’s best players can’t agree on the new Saudi-financed golf tour. Here’s what you need to know.

articles.title: Expert Picks: Who Will Win the Belmont Stakes?
articles.description: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert assess the contenders for the 154th Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

articles.title: Rangers Cede Control of Conference Finals to the Lightning
articles.description: New York has come back throughout the playoffs, and will have to again on Saturday in Tampa with the Lightning one win from a third consecutive trip to the Stanley Cup Finals.

articles.title: Lightning Win Third Straight and Push Rangers to the Brink
articles.description: The Rangers’ first playoff loss at Madison Square Garden since the first round came at an inopportune time for the team, which will face elimination in Game 6 after taking a 2-0 series lead.

articles.title: Where Can I Find a Great Travel Jacket?
articles.description: A reader is looking for something light, wrinkle-proof and dressy-ish to take on trips.

articles.title: A Saloon for the Downtown Fashion Set
articles.description: With the River, a bar in Manhattan’s Chinatown, Emily Bode and Green River Project have expanded their wood-stained empire.

articles.title: Pride Is in the Air
articles.description: All the looks that are fit to print from the Monster x Coach pride party, Guggenheim young collectors gala and the Moth Ball.

articles.title: What Are the Best No-Show Socks?
articles.description: A reader asks for help finding a pair that won’t slip.

articles.title: As the royals emerge on the Buckingham Palace balcony, it’s the ultimate photo op.
articles.description: Elizabeth II was flanked by other members of the royal family, like a summer bouquet in many shades of blue, white and red.

articles.title: How Can I Update My Power Suits?
articles.description: A reader asks for advice on revising their work wardrobe.

articles.title: Winning Looks From the Cannes Film Festival
articles.description: Trends and other takeaways from the fashion show — sorry, movie gathering — on the Croisette.

articles.title: In Kyoto, a Seventh Generation in Metalwork
articles.description: Yoshinaga Nakamura follows his family tradition, making art pieces in silver, as well as jewelry items like hairpins and tiny charms.

articles.title: A Costume Jewelry Brand That Honors Its Fine Jewelry Start
articles.description: Ciner still uses the elevated techniques its founder employed 130 years ago, even though it now works with faux gems and plated metals.

articles.title: The Royal Mint Accessorizes With Jewelry
articles.description: Demand for coins has declined, so the British institution is making gold cuffs, sterling silver hoops and more.

articles.title: Weekly Health Quiz: Covid Vaccines, Cancer and Debt
articles.description: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

articles.title: The Roots of Black Pain in America
articles.description: In “Under the Skin,” Linda Villarosa disproves once and for all the theory that people of color are responsible for their own failed health care.

articles.title: Even with federal funds, U.S. schools still rely on low-cost methods to slow Covid, a study shows.
Breast Cancer Drug Trial Results in ‘Unheard-Of’ Survival
articles.description: For some patients with metastatic tumors not significantly affected by other forms of chemotherapy, the treatment halted their cancer’s growth.

articles.title: Monkeypox Can Be Airborne, Too
articles.description: An abrupt change in C.D.C. guidance underscores a little-known phenomenon: On occasion, monkeypox can be transmitted through aerosols, similar to the coronavirus.

articles.title: As the Great Salt Lake Dries Up, Utah Faces An ‘Environmental Nuclear Bomb’
articles.description: Climate change and rapid population growth are shrinking the lake, creating a bowl of toxic dust that could poison the air around Salt Lake City.

articles.title: F.D.A. advisers recommend the authorization of Covid shots by Novavax, a latecomer in the vaccine race.
articles.description: Clinical trials found the vaccine to work well, but the company has long struggled with manufacturing.

articles.title: Can I Withhold Medical Care From a Bigot?
articles.description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on a physician’s duties.

articles.title: He Helped Cure the ‘London Patient’ of H.I.V. Then He Turned to Covid.
articles.description: Ravindra Gupta, who led the efforts that resulted in the second case of a patient being cured of H.I.V., was drawn into pandemic research.

articles.title: A Cancer Trial’s Unexpected Result: Remission in Every Patient
articles.description: The study was small, and experts say it needs to be replicated. But for 18 people with rectal cancer, the outcome led to “happy tears.”
